TAC's Reticence
The ruckus over the University's anti-solicitation
policies may have come to an end. No one knows for sure
because the Temporary Advisory Council was a little
weak in taking its stand against the restrictions, and
Dean Benton, with whom the final decision rests, was at

But just the same, the TAC deserves congratulations
for recognizing the obvious and doing something about.

dorms, students giving away firearms, and just what
constitutes a public place (which remains unsettled),
the TAC voted to recommend that the University
"commit itself to free and open solicitation in public
places." It seems that the TAC is leaving it up to Dean
Benton to define what its own resolution means--in
keeping with its status as an advisory body. We don't
really expect Dean Benton to come up with an overly
harsh interpretation in this instance, particularly since
it was his action that originally brought the matter
before the public eye but, nevertheless, the TAC's
reticence to define its own action is a bit disenchanting.

Dean Strider told the TAC Friday that Dean Benton
will announce his decision on the reorganization of the
Dean's office at the group's next meeting. It is only right

the shuffle, expected to take effect when Carl Swanson
retires in January from his post as Dean of Undergraduate Studies, is expected to be more farreaching than a new determination of which bureaucrat
moves which papers.
Carl Swanson's post is vital for undergraduates, and
the looming possibility that it may be abolished or even
filled without undergraduate consultation is an absurd
relegation of the undergraduate to the back of the bus.
